dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eight-year-old African-American girl with knockers in hair stands on a desolate sidewalk behind yellow caution tape. She licks a candy and gazes upwards - spellbound. A man in a hazmat suit glides along the pavement, Darth V breaths heaving from his space-mask. He loads pieces of t and plants into hazardous waste bags. In the distance, mo men in hazmats crawl along a decaying dock, collecting various items. The little girl breaks her gaze and begins down the stree running her hand along the caution tape. A voice appears.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why they got suits on and we don't? Something is going on right in front of our face. But you stuck on your i-phone, j-phone 12, whatever. Blow up in your hand! You cant Google whats goin’ on right now. They lucky I’m aman of god now. Or I'd suicide bomb this mother-. Tracking with her, we land on a black man in his Sunday b He stands on a box, shouting at nobody in particular.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: Are ya'll paying attention? Why do they have suits on and we don’t?... Why?!?! Listen to me man! An old lady drives by and honks supportively at the Preac He waves without breaking focus.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: They here to clean this water? Man, this water been funky as the devils mouth for fifty years and now they wanna clean it up?!?!.. Not for you and me, no sir! They got plans for us. He points his chin in disgust at the men in white suits.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They got those suits on lookin like a George Jetson rejects because they weak. Weak hearts. Weak lungs. They cant even breathe out here without a mask on. We were made to be put through hell to be purified. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand what I’m saying brothers and sisters. That’s why I urge you. Do not consummate with white women. Protect the black seed and leave us the hell alone. Unless you came to really help us. Across the street at a run-down bus stop, two African- Americans in their early 20s, JIMMIE FAILS and MONTGOMERY ALLEN, look at the scene, idly regarding it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Crazy what jail will do to a nigga. Montgomery studies the man while he writes in his journal

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: They lucky I’m a man of God now or they'd catch this fade!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You think he rehearses this every morning?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Seems a bit more impromptu.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I think he’s improv-ing.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: It’s 2019 out here, we been yelling about this water since before they was born! Jimmie looks anxiously for the bus down the empty road. Camera begins to slowly push towards him.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Where’s this bus, man? We’re gonna be late.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: We'll get there.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: So I urge y’all to fight for your land!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: We’re not gonna get there, bro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fight for your home! Fight! For! Your! Home!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Let’s skate. Jimmie slowly looks to Mont. Mont turns to Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HP SHIPYARDS - Montgomery and Jimmie ride together on his skateboard. They kick and maneuver in unison. They skate past decaying docks and industrial buildings. preacher's sermon continues as the "Main Score" begins.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This here, THIS is the edge brah. The final frontier of manifest destiny. The last edge of the city, last edge of the country! Man, two steps further and you'd be drinking that filthy salt water. ILLINOIS ST BRIDGE - Jimmie and Mont skate over the bridg

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: We built these ships, dredged these canals, in the San Francisco they never knew existed. HP CORNER STORE - The young men shoot past a corner store with a man sitting in front of a mural of himself. He wav Hunters Point residents are out in their Sunday’s best. PORTOLA ROSE GARDEN - They pass construction workers pull apart a decaying roof across from cookie-cutter homes.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And now they wanna build something new?!? Whole blocks half in the past, half in the future. BERNAL HILL - Jimmie and Mont climb a mountainous hill, t sun rising over the shipyards at their back. As they summ the final red boulder, we see a sprawling civilization be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But should you venture into their San Francisco, the one they pillage for gold, remember your truth in the city of facades. The young men walk hurriedly through an altogether differ world; grand Victorians line the street. Jimmie and Montgomery zip towards the sprawling metropoli The duo bomb a rollercoaster hill. This is a serious jour EXT. DOWNTOWN - MORNING - Mont turns and stares out at al the commuters. He drinks in the city’s new population. TENDERLOIN - The young men pedal in unison past droves of homeless. A shoe flies by their heads. They duck and turn see a crazed man running alongside them, ripping off laye of clothes as he keeps pace. He shouts incoherently.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Look at them look at you, look down at you. But we built them. Jimmie and Montgomery skate past towering buildings. FILLMORE - The young men skate through an altogether different world; grand Victorians line the street.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We are these homes. Their eyes... We narrow in on the details of one very special home as w intercut with details of Jimmie skating towards it: Two big attic windows, like eyes stare down on the street Jimmie staring forward, focused, skates with determinatio

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Their pointed brims. A crooked witch hat tower sprouting from the roof. Jimmie’s beanie rises into frame as he pedals.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: We move as they move. An old curtain flaps in the window. Jimmies clutches his coat, flapping alongside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our sweat, soaked in the wood. Dew drops glisten on hand-carved fish scale walls. Jimmie’s cheeks are dotted with sweat.

dialogues.speaker: PREACHER
dialogues.text: Gilded in our image. Jimmie’s gold chain floats upwards glinting in the light. A tall door with chipped gold leafing catches morning sun The music climbs with each new detail until!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie and Montgomery stand in silence. They look up at a beautiful but crumbling three-story Victorian. Jimmie crosses the street towards The House like a moth t flame, Mont just behind. Jimmie and Mont approach the front gate and peer through bars.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Are you sure they’re gone? Jimmie pushes open the gate.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jim... Jimmie floats up the steps, beckoned by some higher spiri

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) Her car’s gone... A couple with a stroller and dog pass Mont.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (trying to appear normal) How you doing? The couple don’t seem to care. Mont peeks back up to Jimm and closes the gate behind him gently. MONTGOMERY (CONT’D) Let’s check the back, hm? Remember that time he was in the kitchen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, yeah- But bra, did I not tell you... Jimmie presses a ring of paint swatches against the raili

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Periwinkle. Not Black. Mont ascends the step jotting this down into his book.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Mhmm, got it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Ugh. This garden is a nightmare... Jimmie continues up the steps out of frame. 3.1 SIDE ALLEY - Jimmie continues forward, he’s on a miss

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I'll bring my Grandpa’s tools next time.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Sick... 3.2 BACKYARD - Through an empty back window, we see Jimmi up the steps. He peers into The House. A moment of soothi calm and then...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Jesus, wallpaper’s peeling too. These people...

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Yeah but Jim, you’re not gonna go inside. Jimmie’s eyes shift. He has other ideas. He walks down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: They're definitely gone though.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Let’s be quick this time, hm?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah I know. It just takes time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I'll be at my spot. FRONT OF “THE HOUSE" - Montgomery sits at his look-out pe flipping past old sketches of Jimmie. Jimmie paints the windowsill. We cut wide to see he’s standing atop a bird bath. He leans onto his tippy toes to peer inside once more. He sees a sad yellow table in the empty room. He leans forwa little more...a little more, a- WHAM! A croissant hits the window beside him. Jimmie turn

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Jesus! MARY AND TERRY ZWIGOTT stand there. Mary has a fruit in h hand ready to throw.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He’s back again?! GET THE HECK

dialogues.speaker: OUTTA HERE MAN
dialogues.text: She throws it. Terry grabs her arm mid-throw.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Hun, those are 3 dollars!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Stop fffixing my house! Jimmie tries to finish his job vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I’m almost done. Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Go paint the neighbors! Theirs is worse than ours! Jimmie continues to work faster.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I’m almost done!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Look, we will call the cops, man! I’m serious this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re NOT gonna call the cops. Just stop coming back.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Fine. I’1l finish it next time. God.

dialogues.speaker: BATH
dialogues.text: Jimmie jumps off. BULLSEYE! She pegs him with a bread loa Jimmie runs away. She shakes her head in confused frustration.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Water the plants in the back or I will!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ugh! Why am I always the villain?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: Honey, I don’t like these divisive terms like villain.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It’s insulting...I’m at the hospital all day long. I wish I had time to just fix up the house... wierd-ass kid. On the street, Mont and Jimmie make a hasty escape. Mont drops the board and Jimmie leaps atop it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bro, you were supposed to be look out.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got distracted.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You were the one so worried about them coming home! They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie skates down the center of the street, Montgomery trotting beside him. They pass kids hiding in the bushes, men in bowties selli bean pies, girl rappers and their DP shooting a video, an man watching his grandson fix his car.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bra, what if OG is right - you should really stop eating the fish out there.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I think it’s fine, I mean all fish has mercury.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: No, but I saw a seagull with a dick, dude.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Well so, I guess it was male.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Na bra, like a human dick. Something wrong with that water, bra.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Eh, my grandpa said the hazmats are just there to scare us.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Nooo bro, they're not... We push past Jimmie and Montgomery, past rocky projects a hand-painted station wagon, and land on a group congregat in front of Montgomery's home.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Bra, don't kick that Tumbleweave on me. Nitty dodges the ball of dirt, weave, and god knows what. As we near, we see them clearly: NITTY (the group leader) GUNNA (the look out), FRESH (the quiet one), KOFI (Fresh' big cousin), STUNNA (talks too much) and a few others. Although this Greek Chorus' homes are elsewhere in Hunter Point, this slab of concrete is where they live.  10.

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA
dialogues.text: Aye Kofi, I seen your moms, she was missing a little bit on top. The group bursts out laughing. Kofi gives a weak smile, trying to mask his wounded ego. Montgomery and Jimmie reach the front steps of the house.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I mean, we shower in the same water, Jimmie. The Greek Chorus turns - having overheard this.

dialogues.speaker: GUNNA
dialogues.text: So now these niggas showering together?

dialogues.speaker: FRESH
dialogues.text: Probably was.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Thats fruity.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Naw I was trying to tell him don’t eat the fish, it’s toxic.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Well. Duh. They built the atomic bomb right there. The group looks out at the water. Montgomery turns back t Nitty. A small, wry smile spreads across Montgomery's fac

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (whispering to Nitty) I don’t think that’s true. Jimmie and Montgomery slowly shuffle past the Greek Choru to Montgomery's house, an old sea captain's lodgings. Hovering above the house's backyard are the most notoriou housing projects in the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie sits on the couch beside Montgomery and his GRANDP who both clutch beers. Grandpa's smile holds a hint of widowed sadness he's too considerate to burden others wit The shimmering blue light of the TV illuminates the mens' faces as if radiating from an aquarium.  11.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Can I help you? EDMOND O’BRIEN (ON TV) I'd like to see the man in charge.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (whispering to Grandpa) He’s walking him into the Chief's office.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: (smiling) Oh dear... EDMOND O’BRIEN (ON TV) I'd like to report a murder.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Now who's that?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Edward O. Ryan?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Mhm, Edmond O’Brien, that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CHIEF, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Who was murdered? They all lean in. EDMOND O’BRIEN (ON TV) I was. Montgomery and Grandpa chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Oh god.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What? How?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Just watch. Through a window behind the trio, we see Mont's rowboat hitched to a dock across the street. Beyond the dock, the twinkling lights of ships sprinkle the Bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mont lies in bed, writing a note on his wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Mont. Montgomery... How do I get them out of the house?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Hm? We can hear Jimmie Peeing.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What if I pee'd on their table? 12. After a moment, Jimmie peels back a curtain, and leans in Mont’s bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like - I just climb the birdie bath, broke in, and pee'd all over the little stupid yellow table?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Wouldn't that ruin the floors? Jimmie climbs into his cot on the floor, nested snug betw the bathroom and Montgomery’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah I guess you got a point there. Jimmie stares at the ceiling, still thinking. A gunshot reverberates in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: 44 magnum.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: 10 blocks.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Closer.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Hm....Maybe they’d let me live there as like a caretaker for the house.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: We like having you here Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I know bra...But there’s no place like home.  13. Jimmie rolls over and looks at the wall. We see a picture him as a young boy on the front porch with lots of family Beyond the photograph, we see old pin ups, a work To Do l for The House, old photos of The House, and more family photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faint echoes of laughter spill from the house. Below, the Greek Chorus jaw playfully under a streetlight. The Preac walks past them and they fall hush. A distant foghorn gro As he passes out of ear shot, their laughter rises behind him, swallowing him up. Cop car lights flash off screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK - with a pinhole pinch of light. We are a rock in t hand of a child. Mischievous cackles surround us. The chi launches us high into the sky. As we descend back to earth, we tumble towards a group of hidden kids, who all scatter except one. He sees them run and then looks up too late, just as the camera hurtles towards him - WACK - we collide with his head. From the bay, we see two groups of warring neighborhood k hailing scores of rocks at each other from behind makeshi forts. A few scream insults borrowed from older brothers. Montgomery watches the dangerous child's game unfold from serenity of his rowboat a hundred yards out. He sketches strange scene, trying to capture the drama before him, li blueprint for a future stage play. Suddenly, a three-headed fish flops onto the deck of the boat. Montgomery stares at the floundering oddity. A moment later Mont is on the dock shouting lines, leapin back and forth as if playing opposing characters in a sce He’s working out the lines of a shouting match between th preacher and a hazmat clean up man. Mont gets a good idea and jots it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Bloop, bloop.* Red Rock Cod swim in place in an overcrow tank. A hand plunges into the tank and grabs one.  10 11 12 14. Montgomery stands behind the fish counter of the Chinese supermarket, his apron smeared with fish guts. Behind him Mont’s colleague reaches around the tank. Jimmie bored, making a whirlpool with his finger in the open tank.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Did you get any writing done this morning?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Eh. Mngh. Writing is rewriting. It's all a part of it- An old Chinese woman politely tries to flag Mont’s collea

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I can help you, ma’am. Jimmie swigs a Pepsi and Montgomery prepares her meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie weaves down the street on his board. He approaches "The House," and slows to a halt in front. The windows glow, as night approaches. Inside, Mary and T mill about. Jimmie reviews his paint job from days prior, surveys the home's storybook magnificence. His eye catches something. He approaches the house and ya an offending dog doo bag from the front vines. He tosses in the neighbor's yard and skates away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse helps an old man on the steps of a Victorian in t Haight. Jimmie skates in wearing orderly clothes. He clim the steps where a few elderly residents sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PHYLLIS, a frail white woman with big scared eyes, lies o her bed, hair perfectly brushed and draped in jewelry. Sh stares blankly at Jimmie as he removes her pants and prep her for bed. LIZZIE, her pretty granddaughter around Jimmie's age, sit a sofa across the room. Her phone lights her oblivious fa  13 15. Phyllis’ record player begins to skip. Jimmie looks to Li deep in swiping to notice the looping line "over the moun Jimmie places Phyllis on the bed, her pants halfway down.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (to Lizzie) Oh, no, don't get up. Lizzie doesn't seem to hear him. He fixes the needle. He returns to Phyllis and lifts her again. She glances up at appreciatively and begins humming the tune.

dialogues.speaker: PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: Thank you James.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Us natives gotta stick together. Her initial confusion turns to a nodding smile, as if jus remembering she is a native.

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He SO soft tho. You old marshmallow powderpuff ass nigga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunna and Fresh laugh hard as Kofi gets roasts. Nitty pus through the uproar and gets in Kofi’s face, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: You weak brah - you a bitch! Mont, walking home across the street sees Kofi getting pu by his friends. Mont sets his bag down staring intently.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I should snatch your one ass dread lookin like a Rastafarian sperm.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Man, y’all got me fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA
dialogues.text: He got you fucked up!?!? Thats all you got to say.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Man what am I ‘sposed to do take off on him?!?  14 15 16 17 16.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Psh - you know why he ain’t got nothing else to say?!? I put that on the fact that this niggas a bitch brah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montgomery looks deep into the full-length mirror. He cle his throat and takes a nip of whiskey from the cap. He be trying on different voices for size.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: What's up nigga? What...is up nigga? Sup nigguh? Was good neeguh? Hey nigga! How are you nigga? Good day, nigga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie stands behind the front counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie sits on the steep roof of the retirement home, eat canned oysters and surveying the city below. In the far distance, he can see the twinkling lights of " House." He gazes at it like a nightwatchman at his post a the city begins to wake at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie's signature beanie, flannel, and skate-worn khakis strewn across Mont's bed, as if worn by an invisible man. Mont opens the door in his long johns to find Jimmie stan at his mirror. He's in low-hanging jeans and a studded be considering two different goon shirts. Montgomery freezes.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Are you going to see your dad?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I mean, I was thinking about it. But nah. You ready to go?  18 17.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Nearly, I'll get my tools. Mont nods and returns to brushing his teeth as he walks o Jimmie self-consciously removes his fitted cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mont and Jimmie sit at their regular busstop, waiting gardening tools in hand.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Man where is this bus. We got hella gardening.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Hey Jim... didn’t you used to live in that car?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Oh god. The car wipes frame

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: From a house to an El Dorado. A rusty car clunks toward them, duck-farting and hiccupin yellow smoke. They watch the car as it gasps for breath. BOBBY, a middle-aged man with a sunny disposition, sticks head out of the taped-up window.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jimmay!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (unenthusiastically) Hey, Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Haha! Whats your farming ass doing in the street with a rake? Jimmie tracks the car as it huffs its way out of frame. The car does an illegal U-turn, hitting the curb across t street, and screeches to a halt in front of the young men

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Where y'all headed?  19 18. Jimmie checks to make sure the bus isn't coming.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BOBBY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Bobby nudges Jimmie jovially.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jimmie the farmer - with your bitch ass. A children’s 49er’s sticker stuck to the passenger car do Jimmie’s scratches at it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Still the same. Montgomery studies the backseat, which has been converted into a bedroom with satin sheets and window curtains. Lit plastic bags litter the pillows.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah! I like what you and your Pops did with it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: So much you drove off with it?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Aw, I'm just borrowing it. But man, I seen your daddy the other day. That man is alone! Bobby laughs. Jimmie looks confused by this characterizat Mont mumbles to himself in the back as not to eavesdrop.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Wooh! So alone.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I told him get a woman, or a dog! Something!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bro...you live in a car...by yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm not alone! People like me, I'm liked. He over there alone, spitting sunflower seeds in a cup.  19.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Well maybe you should go hang out with him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Maybe YOU should go hang with him! When's the last time YOU seen him? Jimmie looks out the window, sour.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That's why a man has kids, keep him company, shit. The car pulls to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Look at these motherfuckers. You know how many of them Imma outlive? Bobby looks out his window at people in a park on laptops

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Park full of ulcers and panic attacks. Hemorrhoids. Wanting responsibility. Tryna own what’s temporary. Bobby looks to Jimmie, who stares at a burned out empty l

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit, that’s gonna be them next though. Jimmie studies a mustachioed construction worker leaning against the empty lot’s fence, smoking a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Used to be 100 motherfuckers in there. With rent control. They thought that was theirs too. Landlord burned ‘em out. Cuz he thought it was his. But you can’t never own land in America. Jimmie doesn’t respond, transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This car ain’t mine and it wasn’t never yours. Imma’ outlive your ass too, Jimmie.  19.1 20 20. The worker breaths his smoke at Jimmie like a devil. The faint sounds of striking hammers rise. We push towards th worker, over the fence, and in the depths of hot tar fiel Hulking construction men zap at iron with welding torches pound away at hunks of steaming tar like satan’s henchmen The sound of boiling bubbles rise as we cut to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie and Montgomery walk through the Fillmore, gardenin tools in hand. As they approach "The House," Jimmie's eye widen. He continues forward, mouth agape, as men in unifo carry boxes past him. He stands frozen like a zombie. Mary cries into Terry's shoulder as a mover carries a box down the front steps of "The House." Terry looks up to se Jimmie and Montgomery with their tools and puts a hand up if to say not today boys. Jimmie turns to the nearest mover.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, what’s going on? He shrugs and trudges back to the house. ARTURO sits in t truck, shaking his head, upset. Jimmie approaches cautiou

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir, what’s happening?

dialogues.speaker: ARTURO
dialogues.text: She’s beautiful and I like her, but right now I cannot do that, because she fighting.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What? Fighting what, who?

dialogues.speaker: ARTURO
dialogues.text: Fighting because her sister wants to get her out the house. I cannot be here.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Fighting about what?

dialogues.speaker: ARTURO
dialogues.text: Yeah because her mom died and now whose gonna have the house? Who gonna posses the house?  21 22 21.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: But for what?

dialogues.speaker: ARTURO
dialogues.text: That's what white people do, they lose a family and they wanna collect it, and grab it, and posses it. This is mine, this is yours. I cannot help her. It’s unprofessional. Jimmie looks back at Mary sobbing. He glances up at the massive house.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: So what happens to it now? Jimmie stares at Mont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skateboard wheels roar against the pavement as Jimmie pou the concrete, almost in tears. Montgomery runs alongside like a kid who never played spo He glances at Jimmie, wondering if he'll slow down. Jimmie's legs seem to double in speed as his mind races. breaks his long stare to check on Montgomery. He's no lon beside him. He slows to a halt and looks back. Montgomery is kneeled over, panting. He points up.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Wanna...Get...Candy? Jimmie's eyes follow Montgomery's finger up the hill to a line of people filing out of the door of a housing projec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie and Montgomery stand in a line made up of mostly k LORETTA, the proprietor of the makeshift store, sits behi folding table with a cash box on her lap. Darrel, now counting candy bars instead of throwing rocks places them into a purple bag and hands it to his mother.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: 10 bucks, sweetheart.  22.

dialogues.speaker: GROWN ASS MAN
dialogues.text: Since when?!

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Since that’s the best deal you're gonna get for sixty Twix, hon.

dialogues.speaker: GROWN ASS MAN
dialogues.text: Sixty? No miss, I said sixteen. How am I gonna eat 60 Twix?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I don’t know your life.

dialogues.speaker: GROWN ASS MAN
dialogues.text: Man, I’m finna flip this shit. Behind them, Montgomery studies his friend.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Why'd they have to move out because her mother died?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I don't know...I wish they didn't though. They were tasteless but at least they didn't fuck it up. Grown Ass Man exits. Loretta looks up at Jimmie and Mont.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Well if it isn't our own Tyler Perry. When you gonna put me in one of your plays?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (blushes ) Do you have any Saltwater Taffy, Loretta?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: You're the only reason I stock up on that nasty shit, so yes I do. The usual, Jimmie?...Jimmie? Loretta smiles apologetically at those waiting patiently.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Six please.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Grrah - you’re gonna get fat again.  23 24 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mont lays on the sidewalk chewing his candy with his mout open as Jimmie stares in his lap, pensive. A moment passe

dialogues.speaker: ANDY ROY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Eraaay, fuhck youu Jimbo! Jimmie slowly looks up to see ANDY ROY, a weathered, midd aged white skater covered in tats with his pal WHEATBERRY He whisks past, swinging a dead pigeon around like a lass

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Yeah, fuck you back bra. Andy Roy chucks the pigeon at an advertisement.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Jesus. Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: This fool Andy. Me and my dad used to squat with him and these fiends. Andy continues down the empty street throwing up devil ho

dialogues.speaker: ANDY ROY
dialogues.text: Hell ride! HAHA! Jimmie looks over to the ad. A smiling realtor - artfully made-over with a Hitler mustache, devil horns, and 666 sprayed across his forehead - now drips pigeon blood. Something clicks for Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The realtor from the ad, CLAYTON, sits in a small brick office. A framed photo portrait of Ed Lee hangs on his wa Neon from a bar below spills through his window.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: So did I have a dick in my mouth? Or, like, a Hitler mustache? Jimmie smirks, a little restless. Montgomery nods politel

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Hitler mustache.  24.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Fuck dude. They make us put our faces on that stuff, so lame. Guess it works though.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah we're curious about a house on Golden Gate, near Fillmore?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Golden Gate, yeah, okay. Which one?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: 74, it's grey with like gold trim and uh-

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Yup yup, with the witch hat. Jimmie looks impressed.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, exactly. Clayton shifts excitedly in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: That place is pretty special, man. I used to drive past there on my way to school every day.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Where'd you go to school?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: St. Ignatius. You're from here too?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Third generation.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Right on! Honestly, that's the kind of property that got me into this. If I had it, I’d take out the inside, keep the old facade, ya know- But, so it's for sale? I didn't even hear about that.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not sure. It seems like the owner and her sister are fighting over it.  25 25.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: The owner?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Well the lady that was living there. But I guess her mom died.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Oh man. Oof. That sounds like an estate thing. That's a sucky situation. Clayton scans the room, shaking his head. Jimmie looks nervously at Mont.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -..and with a house like that? They'll be fighting over that for years.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: For years?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: While it just sits there, yeah, it’s a pity.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: So it's really just empty?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Yeah, fucked up right? All these people on the street while these big ol’ houses just collect dust. But shit, cold world no blanket. Sorry I couldn't be more helpful.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah... Jimmie stares at Clayton, gears turning. Montgomery looks over at Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie and Mont stand silently staring up at the house. A traces of its former residents are gone, save a pile of newspapers. Through the curtain-less windows, the empty parlor stares back unblinkingly at the young men.  26 26.1 26.2 26.3 26.4 26. Jimmie exhales and starts towards the towering property draped in fog. He makes his way down the side alley, Mont following close behind. Jimmie pushes open a gate to the backyard, revealing an untended garden. They face the back of the house.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bra. A back door window is covered in faded stickers: KEEP TAH BLUE / COEXIST / I'M WITH HER. A Wiccan suncatcher dangle it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: No taste. Jimmie approaches the door. He tries the knob - locked. H shoulders it - barely budges. He steps back, checking the neighbors' windows. Montgomer takes his place beside Jimmie. They share a look. We hear nothing but Jimmie's excited breath. They charge towards the door. Upon impact, WE CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARLOR - A SMASH echoes from the other side of the house. curtain flutters from the distant impact. The room is emp Tomb-like. Its vacancy heightens its magnificence. FRONT HALLWAY - Empty. But the muffled sounds of new life rumbling footsteps and roused voices - creep closer throu the walls and ventilation. ATTIC - Still empty. But the stomping grows louder, breat more life into the creaking floorboards. LIBRARY - Laughter echoes off the walls. The house is com alive. FRONT HALLWAY - Galumphing now thunders off the walls unt SILENCE - Jimmie arrives in front of us. We slowly draw away from him. Jimmie chases after us, as pulled by the spirit of the house. He flies up the spiral staircase and sprints down the hallway. His foot catches a corner, throwing him to the ground. THUD.  27. 26.5 MASTER BEDROOM - Jimmie rolls over onto his back, bl spilling from his lip as he laughs hysterically. As Jimmie catches his breath, a faint voice approaches outside. He picks himself up and walks towards the window A group of tourists on Segways stare up at the house thro the mist. The crowd of expressionless faces look like an in matching tie-dye and helmets. They circle their guide, adjusts his helmet and begins his chalk talk. TOUR GUIDE (CONT’D) The other guides will rattle off some stupid Summer of Love Grateful Jefferson Quicksilverrrey. But you distinguished truth-seekers wanna know about in the real hep-cats who hung out here, like James Baldwin in his stylin’ ascots. Here! In the "Harlem of the West" where Dizzie and Miles would come play after their white people gigs. Where Mayor Moscone got blowjobs from black hookers. Where Jim Jones mixed his first cup of Kool Aid. A couple older tourists look to each other. Their teen be

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Course, ‘long comes Mayor Joe Alioto, spoiling all the fun, leveling the neighborhood in the name of urban renewal. Sorry about your homes, and your funky shops - you can set up a shoe shine stand in the Safeway parking lot! (he gasps for air) And yet, a few glorious homes survived Il Duce’s wrecking ball, like this masterpiece dating clear back to the 1800s.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Na bra. 26.6 EXT. BALCONY - Jimmie pushes the window open and ste

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: Before the black stuff, this was a all Japanese, ‘til FDR’s storm troopers rounded em up into camps-  28.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (yelling) This house was buuh!- Jimmie spits a mouthful of blood to the left of the tour.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry- He wipes his lip dry on his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This was built in the 1940s. The tour guide looks quizzically up at Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: (laughs) Hey there amigo! Uh huh- Let's wave to our neighbor here everybody. A few group members tepidly wave, he lowers his voice so Jimmie wont hear. Jimmie leans forward to listen. TOUR GUIDE (CONT’D) That would be about 100 years late for this style. We can see, just from his gingerbread trim, this was built sometime in the 1850s.
The tour guide smiles embarrassedly at his group.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: Hhhhm gonna have to disagree with you there dudeman. No architect in the 1940s was building in this style.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: That's probably true, but this house wasn't built by an architect. My grandpa built this. The group, including the tour guide, look up at the tower piece of real estate with renewed curiosity.  27 28 29. TOUR GUIDE JIMMIE (CONT’D) Well I- He arrived in WWII, bought this lot, and built this house. The stairs, these windows, the columns, the archways, the witch hat, the balustrades, the fish scales, the little spindles, the balcony, the wall to keep y’all the fuck out - all of it by James Fails the First with his own two hands in 1946. Jimmie looks like a king finally restored to his throne - subjects at his feet, framed in an ornate archway. A tubby man snaps a pic. The guide composes himself seeing he's lost his audience.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: Hm. Thats pretty amazing! Well, on we go to our next stop: the closet Patty Hearst willfully hid herself in. Jimmie smiles proudly as they flee. He turns. Mont leans against a wall of the Master Bedroom, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young men huddle around the orange glow of the firepl roasting hot dogs. The crackling fire almost feels like a beating heart. Their long, phantom shadows climb the high empty walls behind them.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful house, Jim. Jimmie takes that in, knowing Mont wouldn't just say it.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: More beautiful than I could have imagined.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Not there yet but, almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ATTIC - Jimmie lays on the floor of the witch hat, pensiv He stares up at the circular tower’s woodwork. He rises.  28.1 28.2 28.3 28.4 29 30. He glides through the attic like a kid on Christmas morni his flannel worn open like a robe. He looks up at its ste ceilings, remembering what was and imagining what could b FRONT HALLWAY - Jimmie runs his hand along the wood panel of the staircase. PARLOR - Jimmie stands under an archway, blue and green l hits his face.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Mont, wake up. Montgomery starts to wake and looks up at Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Your hair...it fits the archway like a puzzle piece.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Telling you bro, I belong here. ATTIC - Back inside the empty witch hat, Jimmie’s minds e twirls upwards towards the ceiling. We cut to VHS FOOTAGE of: A man clinging to a witch hat as it twirls upwards throug the sky. After a moment, we see a construction crane is lifting the man and the witch hat higher and higher.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And what's happening now?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s flying through the air.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: C’mon now.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s flying through the air.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jimmie, your Grandpa was a Godly man but he did not have super powers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie, Montgomery and Montgomery’s Grandpa sit on the co enraptured by the old home movie. Jimmie looks excited to the narrator for once.  31.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: He’s on a crane, it’s hauling him and the witch hat way high up.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Wait! You got video of that day?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, my dad filmed it.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Hm! The witch hat - and Jimmie’s Grandpa - are lowered until attach to the top of “The House.” Claps and cheers rise f a crowd below. Jimmie’s grandpa waves from up high.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Wait. How do you pause? - I think I saw Willie Mays.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Willie? No, this was after that. Montgomery looks up from his crossword puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Willie Mays was at the house?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Mhm. Willie came and paid his respects like we all did. You'd get here and you'd go see Pastor Jimmie Fails, "the first black man in San Francisco.” Jimmie tries to hide a proud smile. On screen, his grandp looks almost mythical as he descends back down to Earth.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Takes a lot of charisma to let people call you that. But he wasn't far off. Jimmie looks over at a shelf with photo albums.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Allen, I was also wondering can I borrow that one picture?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Sure son, I ain't looking at it.. Jimmie shoots Montgomery an excited look.  30 31 32 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiled walls reverberate with the guitar strums of a greyi black man, his case open for coin. He's turned the Top 40 ballad "How to Save a Life" into melancholic folk. Perhap loves the song. Perhaps he knows his audience. Beside him, a half-sleeping spanger holds a sign that rea I U$ed To liVe here... SF nAtive Jimmie and Montgomery enter frame and carry us beyond the busker. A generous goon drops a bill in his case. His mus echoes on as we follow them down a long tunnel, past a homeless family and droves of desperate masses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BART train howls. Jimmie sits in the window beside Montgomery, holding a crumpled, B&W photo. In it - a dapp young Grandpa Allen hugs a man that must be Jimmie's grandfather, in an elegantly decorated room.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: That's gonna be us in a few hours. We pull wide as the train shoots past cookie cutter homes rolling, sun scorched hills. We're not in Frisco anymore. EXT. WANDA’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON A concrete ceiling. A cloudless blue floor. The young men walk into view, along an upside-down suburban street. A shirtless kid lies on his back across the street, his h hanging upside down just off the curb. A pink lowrider rumbles past. The kid flips over to reorient himself. Jimmie and Montgomery, now right-side up, approach a pebb dashed single story home. Jimmie knocks on the screen doo cow moos from the hill beyond the house.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Oh Jimmie! Jimmie Jimmie Jimmie! WANDA, a middle-aged woman in a bolo tie and hoop earring yanks open the door to hug Jimmie. She rocks him back and forth, then holds him at arms length to get a good look.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: It's so good to see you, sweetie.  33 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome Asian man, RICKY, skates back and forth on in street on Jimmie’s board. Jimmie and Wanda sit in vintage lawn chairs; Wanda in a chaise lounge. Montgomery sprawls on the dead lawn beside them, pulling grass. Wanda cools herself with a battery powered fan. They’re sweaty, overdressed for the burbs.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Man, he better not break my board.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: You should be telling him thank you, he helped me pick out that board. (looks at Ricky lusty) Besides, sometimes it’s nice just to watch. Ricky, do that trick you used to do! Ricky crouches to do an ollie and lands it. Jimmie studies Wanda’s swoon.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Y'all hella cute- uh, how much of the stuff you still have, Auntie?

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: (imitating Jimmie) Oh you wanna see the STUFF? You wanna see the STUFF? (turning to Montgomery) Has he been a good house guest for you? Or does he just show up asking you for your things?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Oh um. Uh - not yet no.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Uh huh, well if you gentlemen can spare the time - I did set the beds up in the back and Ricky’s making his adobo.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Auntie I would love to but honestly we should head back tonight. I got my first place.  34.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Woah...wow! In the city? Look at you. Y'all must be doing pretty well to afford a spot there. Wanda smiles at Mont, who drinks his water like he's chew it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we got lucky. It's super empty thoough...

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Uhuh- And your daddy didn't send you here right?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Swear to god.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Cause I hope he's done dragging you into his schemes.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Auntie. This is for us. Jimmie looks her deep in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Okay...Okay! Jayboe, I'm so proud of you man, I miss that place. Ricky eats shit. He looks over at Wanda with a boyish shr She looks at him lustily, a spark reignited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanda opens a garage door, revealing leaning boxes and precious keepsakes. The room is a treasure trove. Jimmie lifts a gorgeous red rug, revealing chest with old robes and thrown-like chairs. He salivates.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Damn, I knew you had some of it, but is this everything?  35.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Everything your dad didn’t smoke up. Jimmie nods.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Sorry hun, that came out a little harsh.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Jimmie lifts what appears to be an old champagne bottle, accidentally revealing a hidden cigarette dispenser withi fan of old, yellowed Marlboros blossom out.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Woah. That's mainey.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: I always had a feeling - out of the family, you'd be the one to come looking for this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What's that? Jimmie walks towards a round table with a mic and headpho beside a Tiffany lamp.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Oh that's my own little thing. From now. You know I always wanted to be a DJ.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I didn't know that.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, and it's a nice way to get to know people out here. I just ask ‘em questions and record it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: That's dope.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: I'll have Ricky play it for you on the way back. He can drive y'all.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Thank you auntie. I didn't wanna ask, but...  35 36. Jimmie bats his lashes coyly.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Psh, he doesn't mind, right Ricky? Ricky shrugs obligingly.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Be nice to move somebody back for once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear nothing but a microphone crackling. Then bubbles. Jimmie and Montgomery sit in the back of a stake bed truc with chicken wire walls, surrounded by unique furniture. Golden light strikes the rows of crops as they fly by. Th clean lines dance in perfect rhythm, one after the next.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sometimes, after a long day, I like to come home and put my head against Ponchy's chest. (giggles) And when he takes a sip of beer, I can hear the bubbles, um, bubbling.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mhm, please thank Ponchy for letting us put a mic on his tummy. We hear the women laugh as the bubbles fizz and pop. Ricky smiles, as if hearing Wanda's laugh makes him miss

dialogues.speaker: WANDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And who's this we have here? A dog snores loudly.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, Pepper only snores like this when she's tuckered out from a long hike. So that usually makes me feel good, like we had an eventful day. Ricky leans back and slides open the cab window. He shout but we can barely hear him.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: How y'all doing back there?  36 36.1 36.2 36.3 36.4 36.5 36.6 36.7 37. Jimmie stares out, mesmerized by the miles of farmland. Montgomery gives a thumbs up, his hair rippling in the wi

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I suppose, most of the sounds I like are probably pretty regular.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (in a punch-in) Far from it. Today we're joined by our wonderful neighbor Jane from Pine St. And now I encourage you to listen to the sounds of your home. The truck disappears into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. "THE HOUSE" MULTIPLE ROOMS
dialogues.text: 2ND FLOOR BUTLER STAIR - The sound of floorboards creakin Ricky, Jimmie and Mont walk up the noisy steps, hands ful furniture. MASTER BATHROOM - The sound of rumbling pipes. Jimmie tur on a sink. His eyes track the sound of flowing water thro the walls, until water gushes out of the faucet. CONSERVATORY - The sound of a flame catching. Jimmie ligh the gas sconce with a match. The hallway illuminates with warm yellow glow. LIBRARY - The sound of an old ticking clock. Mont inspect the title of a book then slides it into a shelf by an old exposed clock. FRONT HALLWAY - The sound of a thunderous pipe organ. Jim plays an organ built into the walls. Dust shoots out of t pipes. PARLOR - Mont runs a finger along the beads of a glass la ATTIC - The sound of wind howling and windows shaking. Ri peels away, waving bye to the young men through the windo EXT. “THE HOUSE” - All the sounds culminate in a full cho It's as if the skeleton of the house - now filled with furniture and people - has pulsing organs and blood pumpi through it. A toilet flushes. Montgomery picks up the final furniture off the street an starts towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: So Ricky never lived here, eh?  38.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Nah, Wanda was in this rock climbing phase, dating this white dude. Jimmie begins to lift a rug when he notices TIM ELLORY - retired cashmere liberal with remnants of a Connecticut accent - across the street. Tim surveys the scene trying to stare, while his dog poops. Jimmie trots down the steps and towards the man, with war purpose. Tim looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Hi sir. I'm Jimmie Fails, we haven't yet had the chance to meet. Jimmie wipes his dusty hand and extends it. Tim takes it instinctively. Jimmie shakes as if sealing a deal.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Welcome to the neighborhood!

dialogues.speaker: TIM ELLORY
dialogues.text: A-ha ah, yes! Welcome. Tim! Tim Ellory. Mid-shake, Tim looks back at the house - a few pieces of stunning, antique furniture remain on the street while Montgomery works away in the window.

dialogues.speaker: TIM ELLORY
dialogues.text: Geez, fast moving market huh, I don't remember a sign going up.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Didn't need to, but look Tim - I really want you to know I’m gonna to be the best neighbor you ever had.

dialogues.speaker: TIM ELLORY
dialogues.text: Well...alright Jimmie. Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: My pleasure. You'll have to pardon me, we've got lots to do.

dialogues.speaker: TIM ELLORY
dialogues.text: Oh, of course. Jimmie half-bows, then jogs back across the street. He gr an armful of furniture and carries it inside. Tim looks o slightly dazed, as Jimmie joins Montgomery in the window.  36.8 37 39. PARLOR - Their collection of furniture sits in the center the dark empty parlor, like pirates treasure in a hollow cave. The young men study their bounty, moving wrappers strewn about like Christmas morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie lies peacefully on the couch, satin pillows crowni his head. Mont lays on the floor on a slapdash bed of cushions and sheets. Both of them are draped in tapestry-turned-comfor with matching wildlife landscapes. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna drink my coffee and scratch my ass while I read the paper.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You don’t even read the paper.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Cuz I never had a home to read it in. A hint of excitement enters Montgomery’s face.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You think this can be really be our home? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. (beat) I just don’t want to have to keep it secret, and lie, you know.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Sometimes you have to lie.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Plus, I think you need to be here. The house needs you. Though I might be crazy.  38 39 40.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You're right though. Cuz you know what’d be actually crazy? Leaving it empty... Just sitting outside, staring at it. That’s actually crazy. We could throw a party... Or put on one of your plays. Montgomery’s toes wiggle at the prospect of it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We could yell...AHHHHHH!

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: The neighbors?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Zeeeeeeeeeeeee-hooooo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie sits on the back of a food truck, grinning mischievously. He hangs on tightly as the truck zigzags o and through the roller coaster hills.

dialogues.speaker: BITCH.
dialogues.text: Silhouetted against a violent orange sky like shadow pupp the Greek Chorus' arms flail in profile as they yell.

dialogues.speaker: GUNNA
dialogues.text: (to Nitty) A van pulled up last night and Kofi ran off like a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Never bra, I didn't even see them niggas!

dialogues.speaker: FRESH
dialogues.text: Quit lying bra, you saw ‘em.  4l.

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA
dialogues.text: (to Nitty) He a liability bra. Li-a-bil-i-ty! Montgomery watches from across the street, captivated by theatrically of the tableau. Through his eyes, it looks l a stage production. Fists slap together. Mouths hurl slurs and saliva. A pair of eyes cry angrily.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Alright, alright, everybody shut up. Kofi. What happened? Kofi avoids eye-contact.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Did you run, bra?

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Na, I didn’t run.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Hit me.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Hit me.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: For what? You my folks!

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Fucking hit me!

dialogues.speaker: FRESH
dialogues.text: Kofi! Hit that nigga! Nitty socks Kofi chest, knocking the wind out of him.

dialogues.speaker: GUNNA
dialogues.text: Wow, he actually soft! Kofi shoves Nitty back, weak.  40 40.1 4l 42.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Haha! GOD DAMNIT man. Who brought this nigga?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s great! That’s great! Yes! They turn to see Montgomery crossing the street. He approaches Nitty.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: What are we...hm....I believe you. Montgomery turns to each member of the group, giving note like a theater director. We scan their confused faces. He arrives at Kofi.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You're okay there. Montgomery lingers for a moment, then marches back across street.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Keep building it!

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA
dialogues.text: Man, take yo' ass in the house!

dialogues.speaker: FRESH
dialogues.text: C'mon bra, he's retarded.

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA
dialogues.text: And!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red autumn leaves flit downwards like snowfall. We descen with them past each gorgeous story and land on Montgomery the front yard, attempting to catch them with a garbage b Jimmie cleans the roof’s gutter, cig in his mouth. INT. “THE HOUSE” PARLOR - AFTERNOON Jimmie and Montgomery hang a large photograph of Yosemite a picture ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie leans off the edge of the balcony, a rope tied to belt. He touches up the gold paint he can now finally rea  42 43 43. INT. "THE HOUSE" BUTLER’S STAIRS - AFTERNOON Jimmie stands at the bottom of a grand, but worn-out staircase. He sips coffee from a mug.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: When you drop in bra, lean back. At the top of steps, Montgomery stands awkwardly on Jimmi skateboard. He precariously leans over the top step, wher wooden planks have been laid to make a path down the stai

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna lean forward.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bra. No.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Why would-

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Cause I'm gonna get nervous. I'm just gonna go with that.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Just- Bra. LEAN BACK. From the start or your gonna fuck your sh- Montgomery drops the board. He leans forward and tumbles the steps like a cat trying to swim. He lands upside down

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie carefully peels away old wallpaper, revealing long hidden wood beneath. Montgomery lays crumpled on the floo dusty and scraped up from his tumble. He scratches away g residue from the wall, groaning.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bruh it’s still not separating.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (groaning) Just gotta dampen it more.  44 45

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I specifically said backwards, bra.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I wanted to know what it feels like when you eat shit. Jimmie shakes his head, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black HOMELESS OPERA SINGER belts "O mio babbino caro" perfect Italian. His booming voice almost drowns out a co fighting down the street. A strung-out man dances along. Jimmie watches, transfixed. Instead of his signature flan and black beanie, he's wearing the goon clothes he'd trie in Montgomery's mirror. Jimmie stashes his board in a bush beside the singer and him a dollar. He crosses the street into a brick building We tilt up the building to the 13tn floor. A man sits in window, like a deposed king banished to some sequestered tower. He watches the little people scurry about as he sp sunflower seeds at the world below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie flips through pirated DVDs in cellophane bags. The homemade labels read: UNDER SIEGE. CLIFFHANGER. THE PATRI JAMES SR. I seen your cousin Al the other day. Down there struttin’ around, like a Frisco fruit cup. I know his daddy mad as hell! JAMES SR., a once-athletic man with a hard-earned rasp, s at a table cutting a cover for Chuck Norris' INVASION USA Bags of DVDs and sunflower seeds surround him. JAMES SR. You still skateboarding?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Nah. JAMES SR. Hm.  45.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What? JAMES SR. C'mere and help me cut these out. Jimmie joins his dad at the table, adopting a slightly different voice than we've heard him use with Montgomery.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Remember that warehouse we squatted at with Andy and them? JAMES SR. Who? Those satanists?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Ha, yeah, we lost it cause we didn't pay taxes, right? JAMES SR. Hell na, I paid OUR share of property tax on that. But who cares, ol’ drafty-ass roach nest.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: But so, why were you doing all that? We were able to stay there right? Nobody was fucking with us. JAMES SR. At the time, yeah, but we were trying to get it so if the cops showed up, we could say we paid taxes and they’d have to leave us the fuck alone. Shit, it was that or sleeping on the street with your little ass. Jimmie nods unsentimentally processing the information.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Right, appreciate it dad. So... if I'm at a place now, owners left it, and I'm gonna pay taxes- JAMES SR. And you put the gas and electric in your name?  46.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Right, I'm doing that next. But, if I been working on it for 3 years, rent doesn't have to be cash, right? Labor counts as payment? JAMES SR. You've been working on a house 3 years? What you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Painting, gardening, I fixed the stairs up. I prolly still got a bunch of the receipts too. JAMES SR. Okay, okay! You doing it like your old man. That's good. And nobody's come by to check on it?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Nope, it's empty. JAMES SR. Good, that buys you time. They been gone 3 years?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Na, just recently. JAMES SR. Wait what? You were doing work while they were still in it?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. JAMES SR. Where's this house?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: It's the house, in Fillmore. Jimmie's dad stops smiling. JAMES SR. What house?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Our old house. JAMES SR. Fuck you mean our old house? Have you seen that house?  46 47.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I go there a lot. JAMES SR. Then you would know that’s not your house. And that’s not your black ass neighborhood. James Sr. angrily spits a mouthful of sunflower seeds. JAMES SR. Little disrespectful, lying ass...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What? I'm not- JAMES SR. Nigga, I know you skateboard.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Oka- JAMES SR. Yeah I see all the shit down there, everybody's little path. I'm like 30 steps ahead of y’all. He takes a big swig of seeds. They fall back into silence. Jimmie picks up the scissors starts cutting the labels. JAMES SR. Go on and get. Messing up my day. Jimmie stares at him, frozen. JAMES SR. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie sits despondent at a bus stop, his mind still replaying the conversation as his leg restlessly taps awa A gentleman with a grey pony tail and orange skin enters frame. With the exception of tennis shoes, a backpack, an lei around his beck, he is completely naked. He puts a to seat cover on the seat next to Jimmie and sits down. Jimmie is unfazed - he’s seen this a million times.  47 48 48.

dialogues.speaker: NAKED MAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, have you been waiting long?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (vacantly) Hella long, bro. I might just skate.

dialogues.speaker: NAKED MAN
dialogues.text: Oh that's nice. The men turn to see a cable-car-on-wheels thumping toward them with drunk partygoers spilling over the railings. The vehicle slows to a halt in front of them. ZACH a blac techie rips off his knock-off Ray-Ban's to get a better l

dialogues.speaker: ZACH
dialogues.text: Oo! This guy fucks! Ey. Sundeep!!! Bro... This guy fucks! The others notice. Naked Man shrugs with an obliging chuc

dialogues.speaker: THIS GUY FUCKS. THIS. GUY. FUCKS.
dialogues.text: Naked Man offers a polite wave. The bus pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: NAKED MAN
dialogues.text: Oh, this city.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I already know bra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie bombs an epic hill, pink and purple clouds behind His board wobbles more...and more...and PHWACK! He dives first into the ground as we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie hammers angrily at a wooden door frame. BOOM-BOOM- BOOM. Blood from his scrape drips down his bare shoulder. BOOM-BOOM-CRACK.

dialogues.speaker: FUCK
dialogues.text: Montgomery bursts in covered in paint, a roller in hand.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You okay? Jimmie sits in the door frame of a hidden room behind a f bookcase. He glances back at Mont, a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Jimmie laughs, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: This little room I used to come in when my dad was doing his thing. Cool right?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Yeah man. Did you see him today? Jimmie scoots out as Montgomery gently swings the false w Light swings back and forth on Jimmie’s otherwise dark fa

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: He said this was a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Well what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I thought you said he’s an idiot. Jimmie tries not to chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What if we shouldn’t be here though?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Who should be here more? Some millionaire? Montgomery looks up to the wood Jimmie was working on.  49 50 50.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: They'd want it cause it looks nice. You're the reason it looks nice.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I dunno- DING DONG. Jimmie spins to shut the secret door. Darkness

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: The fuck?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I invited somebody.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. "THE HOUSE" FRONT HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Montgomery open the door. Kofi stands there, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: What's good nigga? Glad you could make it. Kofi slowly enters and slaps fives with Montgomery.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Pardon me for a sec. Mont scurries off as Kofi takes in the biggest house he’s ever been in.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Y'all got a organ? Kofi notices Jimmie staring at him from the end of the ha Kofi nods ‘whats up.’ Jimmie nods back slowly. Kofi conti to the parlor.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Got columns and shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kofi shifts in a stiff Victorian chair. He looks over Jim a little confused by his blood-stained goon clothes. Montgomery smiles politely. Flower arrangements plucked f neighbors gardens sprinkle the room. None of them quite know how to act under these foreign circumstances. All three have beer in mismatched glass chalices.  51. An eerie creaking sound comes from upstairs. Kofi looks around the candlelit room.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: It's just y'all here?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It just makes noises. Kofi scans the highest ceilings he’s ever seen. Montgomery studies Kofi.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Nice to see you in that chair. I didn’t know you'd pick that one, but I think I’m glad you did. It looks good on you.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: (eying the chair) Yeah right on bro, this shit kinda awkward. But this place hella cool.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Jimmie's been doing a lot to fix it up.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: How'd y'all get this?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: It’s Jimmie’s, his grandpa built it. He was the first black man in San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Oh shit, this that house. (to Montgomery) Man, he used to always talk about this. But you know niggas in group homes be exaggerating, tryna' act special. But you were foreal huh? Jimmie nods, as Kofi looks around.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You were in a group home?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. For like a year.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Huh.  51 52. Something clicks for Montgomery. He looks back at the two them. A beat passes.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You guys wanna go for a schvitz? Jimmie turns, a smile cracks through.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: A schwitz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trio sit in a cloud of smoke and steam in a homemade sauna. Montgomery has his shirt off, Jimmie and Kofi have opted to sweat through all their clothes. Loretta's candy bags litter the cedar seats. Jimmie takes final puff off a blunt and tries to pass it, no takers.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Wait, your grandpa made this, too?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Nah, these white people did.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: How was he the first, though? (turning to Montgomery) This nigga woofin'. Jimmie adopts a cadence that Montgomery hasn't heard.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Na bra, swear to god, whole neighborhood was, like, a ghost town when he came from New Orleans. It'd all been Japanese, but-

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Fillmoe? Psh never, bra.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But they all got rounded up into War camps. And my grandpa wasn’t tryna move into someone else's shit- Not like that. So he built this.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Fuuuuck.  53.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Fuuuuck. The trio fall silent.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You still skate?

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Na.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Aw, you were raw, bra.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Yeah- remember when Rick got caught stealing from the candy lady? Jimmie bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Braaaa. He was an ugly crier!

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Bra, I'm sayin'! And then Ms. Homer made him shave his head...But her white ass fucked up his lining. So his shit was crooked as fuck.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Lombard-Street-looking-ass...

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: BRUH! Lombard Street thooough- Kofi falls onto the floor giggling.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Bra, I can't even...I'm finna piss myself. Y'all got a bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Down the hall. The room with the 1il' claw-foot tub.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Bet. Man, you niggas made it, man. That’s crazy. Kofi exits with a puff of steam, chuckling. Jimmie smiles at Montgomery, grateful.  52 53 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie grabs a screw from between his lips and drills it a new lock on the front door. He shuts it, proudly locks and looks over at Mont, deeply focused on reviving the or

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You should uh...you should have a room, bro. Montgomery looks up at Jimmie, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Aw Jim, that’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Nah, seriously. I've been in your space forever - this spots yours too, you know.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Any room?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I mean...sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if pulled by some spirit, Montgomery floats forward. H eyes catch the corners of various rooms as he ambles forw Jimmie stands on a chair in the background fiddling with electrical box. He flips a nob and the room lights up wit warm glow. Montgomery enters the dining room, his head turned up at heavens. It’s his very own Sistine Chapel: paintings of colorful birds spread their wings across the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Is this one okay?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah...I mean, you sure you want the dining room? Montgomery nods to himself, taking it all in. He begins t measure the wall with his wingspan, muttering calculation

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: It's perfect.  55.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dream big bra, it's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montgomery, wearing an old werewolf mask, sorts through p and costumes. Only a few tools remain hanging on his once covered walls, the rest packed away in scattered milk cra He begins organizing metal pulleys and clews into a crate with other stage rigging materials. In the next room, Jimmie paces back and forth on the phon

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No the power’s been on. I just need the bill in my name - uh huh. Grandpa enters, the phone cord hitting his chest. He lift and feels his way into Montgomery's room.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Great, when will I get the first invoice?...And there's no way you can mail that sooner?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: (quietly) He talking about paying some bills? Mont expertly wraps a cable and packs it, mask still on.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I wouldn't say no if he offered to chip in a little more.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: He already pays half, Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Well he's been here for a while now. He isn't exactly family.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I think he knows that. Montgomery removes the mask, putting it in a crate. He pu a drill from a hook on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: So what's all this you're up to in here?  55 56.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Just packing some things. It's for a project.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Since when? We haven't even talked about the characters yet?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: It's a- well I'm still working- don't quite have a plot yet.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: We could brainstorm a little.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: We’re in a bit of a rush, but I'd love to soon.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Oh sure. Thats okay, son. Jimmie enters.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You about ready bra? Grandpa stands up.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Well, whatever it is I’m proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catcalls from the Greek Chorus fail to land on Montgomery head cocked listening, fascinated. He pushes a cart full crates, various prop hats stacked atop his head.

dialogues.speaker: FRESH
dialogues.text: Oooh Monty, that’s hard.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s clean, you should start rocking that bra-bra. Jimmie hauls a chest of Montgomery's gear, shaking his he

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA
dialogues.text: Hey Monty whats under that coat? You flashing yo weenie to all the girls, huh?  57. Jimmie yells back as he continues walking.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bro, with that hair, you look like a Simpson. The Greek Chorus burst out laughing. Mont smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA
dialogues.text: Bra you got one shirt! You look like a fiend! Jimmie cracks a half-smile.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Just like his momma and his daddy... Yeah I remember. Jimmie's smile vanishes. He turns to face Kofi.

dialogues.speaker: NITTY
dialogues.text: Family of fiends!

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: He probably got lace curtains in there for they little dollhouse. The men around Kofi crack up.

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Swear to god bra, two grown-ass men playing house! With candles and shit! I was dying!

dialogues.speaker: GUNNA
dialogues.text: (laughing) Look, this motherfucker so mad!

dialogues.speaker: KOFI
dialogues.text: Shoo, bra! Get on! Aye Mont’ teach him how to vanish! FRESH pretends to flick a match. Jimmie breaks his stare, turns, and walks towards Montgom Nitty hugs Kofi, proudly.

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kof’ got his balls back!  56 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
