dialogues.text: An expressive sketch of the Greek Chorus captures the joy moment they humiliated someone, Kofi standing front and center. Montgomery's hand enters and plucks out the Rockwellian pencil shading on FRESH. Jimmie stands in an old robe at the corner whisking eggs a fork. He watches Montgomery.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You're really drawing them?...Al1 they do is talk shit.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You talked shit when I met you.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: No I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You did. It’s fine though. Jimmie watches Montgomery sip a beer and continue sketchi

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Well why did you hang out with me then?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You care about things. I liked you. He grabs a chewed-up pencil from his crate of art supplie

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You really don’t give a fuck what anybody says?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t get to appreciate them just cuz they’re mean to me? That seems silly. Jimmie furrows his brow, confused. He looks up and sees a neighbor through the window whisking eggs in her kitchen. studies the middle-aged woman in her robe.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Let’s go out. Dreamy, sweeping strings appear.  57 57.1 57.2 58 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. VR WINDOW - Jimmie and Mont sit in the dark, sipping 40's of beer. They peer into a window as if watching tv. A man in a VR helmet and underwear reaches blindly in an empty room. After a lonely moment, a girl steps into view wearing a matching helmet and oversized shirt. They swat virtual predators, finally bumping into each other. They off the masks and laugh hysterically. EXT. SPLIT WINDOW - Two young women sit on opposite sides a converted bedroom, split down the middle by a hanging b sheet. Woman #1's yoga routine is interrupted by a knock the door. A man enters her side, tiptoes past her, ducks under the sheet-wall, and embraces Woman #2.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bro, that's supposed to be a living room. Jimmie and Montgomery study the respective sides of the girls' mantle, each with differing decorations.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: They would've done the same shit to our house. Putting 5 people ina room.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: We're quite fortunate. They clink bottles. EXT. HOUSE PARTY WINDOW - A large Victorian pulses with t vibrations of music and the energy of millennials. A man dances in a corner window. His gaze catches Jimmie and Montgomery ogling from outside. He smiles and waves them The young men tipsily look around, alarmed someone has ca their peeping. They look back up at the house. Partygoers hang over the second story balcony. A couple s on a fire escape; legs dangling, throwing feathers. Jimmie finishes his bottle. The duo and walk into towards camera, until their bodies black out the frame. They step through the other side, into the world they'd been watchi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie and Montgomery enter the house, passing various partygoers.  59 60 60. They stop and watch a man with Robert-Plant-hair and musi theater-gusto hand-dances and sing to a song playing overhead. Jimmie stares at him, eyes glazed. Montgomery grabs a bot off the shelf and swigs it, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERENA, a Berkeley girl conceived to Paul Simon, nods.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You know the wallpaper on the outside wall is hella harder to remove because it’s moist, like condensation, but then when you finally do, you see they used WHITE glue. Like fucking Elmer’s. Like what was the thought process?

dialogues.speaker: SERENA
dialogues.text: Yeah, no idea.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. But if you wanted to have a tour, that would be fun.

dialogues.speaker: SERENA
dialogues.text: Sounds good - I’m gonna bring these drinks. You're welcome to come -

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, if that’s cool. Jimmie reaches for the beer cups she’s filled.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m talking about this house. It’s stupid. I’m just kinda excited about it. They walk off, revealing a pomade-preened guy explaining Hyphy lingo to a skeptical collegiate black woman. A trans man and his bubbly friend share a sarcastic toast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serena sits on a counter by her friend, BILLY, an intellectual stoner in his grandpa’s PJ’s and Sam, a swee faced dude holding a huge stein of beer.  61 61. Jimmie stands awkwardly at the edge of the group.

dialogues.speaker: SERENA
dialogues.text: She’s this beautiful, vivacious person dating so many cunty guys. It’s like, don’t blame the messenger I’m just trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: That’s shitty. Serena turns to him politely.

dialogues.speaker: SERENA
dialogues.text: Yeah it’s hella shitty!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: But if it’s a self esteem issue, what really can you do?

dialogues.speaker: SERENA
dialogues.text: I mean, I told her. I’m pretty sure I told her- you can sleep with Sam if you want. Sam nods sheepishly. Jimmie looks confused. A cheer from outside catches Jimmie’s attention. He looks the window overlooking the backyard. Amidst a small crowd, three young bros violently yank at small pine tree. It sways back and forth as they wrestle

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: So the thinking is, you have sex with someone whose not shitty once- Jimmie watches out the window, a little shocked.

dialogues.speaker: SERENA
dialogues.text: Exactly! And then your bar is like too high for those cunty roadies and untalented comedian guys. A few onlookers outside egg on the men struggling with th sapling. Suddenly, Jimmie appears in frame. He piles on a begins yanking with them, to the rising cheers of the cro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie looks excited to be a part of this team. With his help, the men uproot the tree.  62. BRYAN, a giant, swings it overhead and victoriously drive the root clump into the ground in an explosion of dirt.

dialogues.speaker: AURA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You fucking idiots!! Bryan, what the fuck is wrong with you!! AURA shoots down the back steps, tipsy and enraged. She shoves Bryan back as he chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: Aw, babe, sorry, it's good.

dialogues.speaker: AURA
dialogues.text: What the fuck, my fucking landlordz tree, you assholes!?

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: I’m gonna fix it. I’m gonna fix it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's my bad too. I can help. Jimmie leans over to pick up the tree.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN AURA
dialogues.text: Yeah it’1l be fine. What, who are you? I don't even know you. (turning to Bryan) Tonight was MY night. MY-

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Ah- Okay, who are you. I don't even know you. I'm from here. Aura turns to Jimmie, confused he's still talking to her.

dialogues.speaker: AURA
dialogues.text: Uh what? Like, how did you even get here?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: How did YOU get here? The fuck? I'm born and raised here. I'm third generation.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: Uh, hey bud, uh, we don’t know you. You know? So, go man, alright?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Alright bud. But I'm taking the tree.  62 63 63.

dialogues.speaker: AURA
dialogues.text: No way asshole! Leave the tree!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I feel a connection to it. Jimmie starts towards the steps with the tree.

dialogues.speaker: AURA
dialogues.text: Why could you do thaaat? Brian holds her waist and whispers into her ear.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: Babe...babe...it's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie walks through the kitchen and into the hall, tree tow. He reaches the main room to see the party is in full swing. Mont, bottle in hand, is jamming with the hand-dan

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Aye, c'mon Mont.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Dancing.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bra, I need help with the tree. His frantic dancing slows as he drunkenly notices the branches dragging through the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young men walk home, each carrying sides of the tree.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (loudly) I mean! Jimmie eyes his neighbors' sleepy houses as they go home.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bra, shhh.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: (loudly whispering) I hahd ah grreat time. Youuu, you dodn't dance.  64 65 64.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Shhh, I dance.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Yeaaah you could, but you dodnt- soo why a tree?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I dunno bra. To make a point I guess. Montgomery tugs the tree, stopping them.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Theres no point! You can’t care SO MUCH about what they think. Life isn perzonal. Jimmie turns back.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bra, you don’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bra! You weren’t raised like... I raised myself. You had someone to make you feel good. I had to like adapt and like win over so many people cause I was alone. That’s why I fucking care. Jimmie walks up the steps to the House. Mont remains froz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie lies on his newly-assembled bed. He looks small underneath the steep towering walls, alone for the first night in longer than he can remember. His minds wanders to Serena and he slips his hand under t sheets. Loud drilling and strange space-jazz burst throug the shaking walls from Montgomery's room. He pulls his ha out from the sheets and turns to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie looks out the window at nothing but fog.  66 67 65.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Thick as fuck today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deep hole in the ground looks like a shallow grave. Jimmie crouches above it, digging - his sleeves rolled up biceps covered in dirt, cig hanging from his lip. Montgom hung over, sprawls under the newly planted tree. Jimmie shakes his head as he digs.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: We need fertilizer, shit's dying. Montgomery groans. EXT. “THE HOUSE” FRONT STEPS - AFTERNOON - TRAVELING Jimmie and Mont carry bags overflowing with asters in blo They climb the first flight of stairs and come to a halt. Mary Zwigott, the previous resident, sits on the front st of the house. She looks lifeless. Montgomery looks to Jimmie, unsure if they should run. An almost haunted wind catches the fringe of Mary’s blous and howls through the trees. Mary shakes her head at the memory of her old foe.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (cautiously) Hey. What are you doing here? Mary’s exhaustion gives way to a resigned half-smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What are you ever doing here? Jimmie looks nervous. His eyes drift to the house.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Uh- didn't you move out though? Mary looks past Jimmie at Montgomery, who stands holding flower bags like an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yeah. They changed the locks on me.  68 66. She studies Jimmie’s young face. It’s the first time she’ really looked at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you want, man?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. That sucks. Mary softens a little.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long are you going to be here?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don’t know yet. Our flight's tomorrow so...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Ok. We'll come back tomorrow then. Jimmie nods to Montgomery who lifts the bags. Mary eyes t tools and chuckles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Great. That’s nice. They turn and walk away.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In this crazy fucking city, you're still here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young men sit in the back of the bus, their colorful flowers beside them.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You think she's gonna stay there all night?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Watch bra. We'll come back and she'll be painting the windowsill. Jimmie glances around the bus. Loretta’s former flame with the fez winks at Jimmie. Further down, two oily street kids with white-people-drea and camping backpacks sprawl across the seats. Their pit forces its snout into the girl's lap.  67. Jimmie's nose crinkles, as the dog sniffs her crotch with increasing fervor. The street kids don't seem to notice. A group of people shuffle off and on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Vikki, yes I know what time those meetings start. I’m 23 years clean, I’m the speaker, okay? I...oh my, Vikki Imma call you right back- Brenda drops her phone and jumps towards Jimmie. He stand hug her, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jayboe!- Sir, could you get my phone?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Hi mom. They hug, then sit back down across from each other.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought you and Ron were in LA.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: No, I came back a few months ago. You know your little brothers been asking about you.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Oh, cool - this is my friend, Mont.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Uh huh I’m Jimmie’s mom, oh thank you. Montgomery extends a hand. Brenda shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Pleasure to meet you, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: How long are y'all here?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Oh, still seeing. Brenda nods. A few passengers look up from their phones, puzzled by the nonchalance of the interaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we been staying at the house. You guys could come check it out.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Oh, that's nice.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I mean the house, my dad’s old house. We've been fixing it up and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Ah, we'd love that. We’d love to come over, yes. 68. Brenda smiles vacantly at Montgomery. He gives her an awk smile back. A few quiet seconds pass.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Well I’1l call you. I got your number.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t have a phone?

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Well we'll just stop by then. A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Okay well this our stop.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA
dialogues.text: Okay, good to see you son. She pops up to hug him once more.

dialogues.speaker: BRENDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my god, you’re taller than me now. Jimmie and Montgomery exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus doors open. Through the fog, we slowly start to see two worried pedestrians whisper in hushed tones as they w off. Mont and Jimmie look at them concerned.  69.1 69. At Monts house, candles, flowers, and the Greek Chorus ar gathered, bleary-eyed and dejected on their slab of concr They avoid eye contact with one another, trying to mask t tears. Their matching necklaces hold freshly laminated ph of Kofi with the caption "RIP KOFI." Jimmie and Montgomery freeze. They stare at the Greek Cho first in shocked confusion, then in horror.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What the fuck? What happened? Nobody answers.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What fucking happened?

dialogues.speaker: GUNNA
dialogues.text: They shot bra.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What? Who?...Who?!

dialogues.speaker: GUNNA
dialogues.text: Some niggas, man.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: GUNNA
dialogues.text: He tried to buff em out.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA
dialogues.text: What's with all the questions bra?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I just...I don't get it. We just seen y'all-

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA
dialogues.text: And nigga?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: And I don’t fuckin get it.

dialogues.speaker: STUNNA
dialogues.text: Then get on bra.  70.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: No, what the fuck? It’s my friend too! Stunna approaches Jimmie; eyes angry. Jimmie tenses up, protectively. Stunna wraps Jimmie into a hug so hard the flower bag fal out of Jimmie's hand. Jimmie stares off, expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie and Montgomery sit on the couch, lifeless. Grandpa sits facing the open window where mourners can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: That poor boy. And his mother- A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Jimmie... They look to Grandpa, their bodies frozen.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: I hope I never made you feel like you weren't welcome here. Jimmie's brow furrows, confused.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: No, I never felt like that.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Cause wherever you been, you don’t have to tell me, but you two just stick together.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Of course Mr. Allen. Mont and Jimmie look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I won't always be here.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Grandpa...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Allen, don't worry about us.  71 71.1 71. They wrap their arms around Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Ok. Alright. I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MONTGOMERY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Through the window, we see Nitty under the foggy streetli He stands spiritlessly on his slab. Beside him, a trail of dark soil from Jimmie's flower bag lays tossed like an arching brushtroke. Nothing can be he but the loud thrum of crickets. Montgomery sits in his bed looking out at Nitty stand alo Jimmie sits on the floor where his cot once was.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're listening to the sounds of crickets behind Bill and Sue Selby's home. Something cozy about them - let's listen in. The crickets continue. Jimmie turns to Montgomery. Mont scrolls through his phone, looking at the RIP messag on Kofi’s wall. Mont turns to Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I was writing a play about him, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to stop now... Mont nods to Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know it sounds weird, but I feel like that coulda been me...if not for the house.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You a funny motherfucker Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Man. I wanna go home. Mont looks out the window.  72 72.1 72.2 72.3 73 72. Nitty stands alone on the corner by the vigil, alone. Music begins as-—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. GUNNA’S HOUSE - In the late evening, Gunna consoles son, Darrel, as he tucks him into bed. INT. BOBBY'S CAR - In the dead of night, Bobby plays solitaire as he listens to the radio. His girlfriend smok INT. PREACHER'S HOME - In the early hours of the morning, Preacher adjusts his bow tie in front of the mirror. EXT. HP SHIPYARDS - The Preacher walks down a desolate st under an orange sky. He places his soap box in the middle the frame. He steps on top, takes a deep breath, and just he opens his mouth-

dialogues.speaker: FUCK
dialogues.text: Jimmie and Montgomery stand on the sidewalk in front of “ House” which is now littered with his grandpa's furniture Every last piece from inside lies scattered on the concre like tossed trash from a spurned lover. Jimmie lifts a broken chair, a few shattered splinters ba hold it together.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Oh god. Jimmie mechanically starts problem-solving, collecting de cushions from the sidewalk and tossing them on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: How'd she toss all our shit? He lifts the last cushion to find his cigarette-dispenser broken. He clutches its remains in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I don't think it was her... Jimmie follows Montgomery's worried gaze to a "FOR SALE" with Clayton's face printed on it, smiling back at him.  74 73.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Fucking...Traitor... He storms over and kicks the sign with all his might. Pamphlets fly everywhere. He stares at the advertisement. Something in him changes.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Okay... Okay... He turns back to the strewn furniture and yanks open a toppled set of drawers and pulls out a dark burgundy suit Jimmie starts off. Montgomery follows.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Could you stay and watch the shit? Jimmie drops his board and skates off like a cowboy. Montgomery turns to the orphaned property. He leans down to right a lamp and notices a tossed pamphl He picks it up and inspects it. His brow furrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie sits antsy, wearing the burgundy suit that was cle tailored to the larger figure of his grandfather. He taps shoes against the cold marble and looks across at a Latin man in a J.C. Penney suit hammering away at a keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sorry, how can I help you today?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I want to buy a house.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: A house! That's exciting. Are you working with an agent?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: No, do I need to?

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: No, not necessarily. Do you have a price range in mind?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I have a house in mind.  74.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: Huh, okay. And it's on the market, I assume? How much are they asking?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: At least 4 million.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: Ok and how much would you be willing to put down?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: How much is usual?

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: Well, typically we'd be looking to secure at least 20%.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have that.

dialogues.speaker: BANKER
dialogues.text: Sure that’s understandable. It’s going to be hard to land a place like that but suppose I asked instead - how much do you make per -

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: No no look, I get it. You're gonna type up all the answers I say and none of ‘em are going to work in my favor. I'm young, I'm black, I'm not rich. I came here knowing all that. But let's be real - you also got a quota to meet. I'm not calling you a predator-

dialogues.speaker: BANKER JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) -but you're trying to make your Sir. Thats not how this works- money. So let me help you that... Give me whatever deal you gotta give me. I don't care what it is. Cuz unlike all the other people that default, this is the only house I'll ever want. So I'll never miss a monthly bill. Ever-

dialogues.speaker: BANKER JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Give me your highest interest No I understand you feel that rate. Fuck me. You don't ev sir but- have to feel bad. Cuz I'm going to pay back every single cent.  75 75.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: OK OK you got me. YOU WIN! You charming bastard. Clayton fake-laughs into his phone and looks over to Montgomery, who sits across from him. Montgomery's eyes wander anxiously around the messy office. Clayton hangs u

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: How's it going man?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Fine sir. I noticed the house we'd discussed is now for sale. Clayton leans back his seat, his eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: There were some alarming things in your literature I thought you might want to know. And certainly the Bureau of Real Estate would.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Uh huh... Montgomery steadies his shaking hand, and raises the pamphlet.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: This says the property has a view of the Golden Gate? Which I don't think is true, well it isn't. Clayton's brow furrows.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: It also claims to have all original "fixtures, floors and faucets". Clayton nods slowly.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: And are you planning on disclosing there's no septic Fresh? So any day now, the garden could be flooded with...shit.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Where's this going man?  76.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Well, together this seems like false advertising, which is grounds to void a sale. Potentially revoke a license. Perhaps it isn’t worth it to you to take this on.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I thought it might've been you guys.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: What's your deal man?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I don’t have a deal.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Look, someone else on this floor would've got it if it wasn't me...at least I’m from here, right? Montgomery tries his best to stare down Clayton, and hide nervous hands under the table.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I put your stuff on the street. I could've had it trucked off but I left it out for you guys.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I'm serious. I will report you.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: For what? Listing a view of the bridge? And fixtures? I literally copy pasted that shit. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Well you're lying about the history of the house. You're saying here it's 100 years older than it actually is.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: No I'm not?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Yes, you are. James Fails built this house in 1946.  76 77.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: James who? Clayton goes into his desk. He pulls out a photocopy of a very old document.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? 1857. Architect's Gil-hoo-ley- some shit. All oxygen leaves Montgomery's lungs.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Look, if you need a week to find somewhere else, then take it. But don't try to pull some squatters rights shit on me, man. Clayton tosses Jimmie's electric bill across the table.

dialogues.speaker: CLAYTON
dialogues.text: I know your name. I don't want to call the cops. I don't want to do that to you. Montgomery stares at Clayton, shell-shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montgomery arrives home to find the furniture is gone. Al that remains is the couch, upside-down. Mont climbs over and looks up. Jimmie sits like a gargoyle on the front porch rail above soaked in sweat. He tranquilly smokes. Montgomery climbs the last step. He studies Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Where’d you go?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Doesn't even matter bra. I got everything inside... except the couch. Shit fell on me. Jimmie laughs darkly. Montgomery looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Jim, I spoke to the realtor-

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Fuck that guy.  78.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Yeah well he’s gonna keep throwing us out. And eventually call the cops. Jimmie shakes his head, stewing. MONTGOMERY (CONT’D) I don’t know how much longer we can keep doing this.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I understand if you can’t, but I’m not leaving bro.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Jimmie, he said your-

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Where else am I gonna go? My dads in an SRO. My aunt’s out in bumfuck. My mom...I don’t even know where my mom is. I’m not leaving. I’m the last one left.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: We have my house-

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I can’t go back there bro. Mont starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bro...don’t cry...this house, this is what I do. It’s what WE do. Shit, you said it - who deserves to be here more than us? Right? This place is ours. We can’t just give up now. We gotta fight, right? Mont wipes away his tears and tries to force a smile.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right? Mont nods, a cancerous lump in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Yeah...yeah, you’re right. I’m with you Jim. Jimmie nods appreciatively at Mont and looks away.  77 78 78.1 78.2 78.3 78.4 78.5 78.6 79. Mont stares at Jimmie long and hard. An idea begins to br

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montgomery scribbles furiously into a notepad. He rips ou the sheet, places it onto a growing stack, and cracks his back. The pocket doors slide open behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh shit. You're writing?! Mont turns to see Jimmie in his doorway. Mont nods solemn

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: It's a play. I'd like to put it on here in a week. If that's alright?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Fuck yeah. Get it bra! Jimmie exits. Montgomery turns back to his opus. A soulful voice begins singing Scott McKenzie’s “If You’r Going to San Francisco.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. HAIGHT ST. - Mike Marshall croons for passing touris INT. "THE HOUSE" DINING ROOM - Montgomery sits at a sewin machine stitching together two different t-shirts. EXT. "THE HOUSE" FRONT STAIRWELL - Jimmie discovers a new realtor sign affixed to the front gate. He tears it down. Mont watches from the top of the stairs, worried. EXT. HP SHIPYARDS - Montgomery hands a flier for his play the preacher, who sits on his box eating a sandwich. EXT. “THE HOUSE” NEIGHBORHOOD -Jimmie hands fliers to whi neighbors, calling out to them like a carnie. INT. "THE HOUSE" CORNER OF A ROOM - Montgomery finds Jimm with a hammer in hand, sleeping. He pulls a blanket on hi EXT. HP BAY - Montgomery shouts lines, leaping from one s of his boat to the other. He rehearses with himself, as i playing opposing characters in a scene.  78.7 78.8 78.9 79 80 80. EXT. “THE HOUSE” SIDE ALLEY - Jimmie looks up from his gardening to see a pair of drones flying overhead. INT. "THE HOUSE" BUTLER’S STAIR - Montgomery watches Jimm with troubled eyes, as Jimmie lacquers the step. A script drops. He grabs it and looks up at Montgomery above.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Damn, you wrote all this?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: There’s more...but I’d rather you see that in person. EXT. HAIGHT ST. - Montgomery stands intrigued watching Mi Marshall sing his heart out. A man on a monowheel zips pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Velvet curtains frame white text projected on the back wa The text recalls Old Hollywood posters:

dialogues.speaker: THE LAST BLACK MAN IN SAN FRANCISCO
dialogues.text: a Stage Play by Montgomery Allen As the acapella voices compete for the last note, we pull back to see chairs now arranged in precise rows. DING DONG.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Montgomery?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shit. Hella fucking early. Jimmie carries us down the stairs towards the front door. house looks better than it ever has, in near museum condi

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. "THE HOUSE" MULTIPLE ROOMS
dialogues.text: Through stained glass with a crest of a “T,” we see Jimmi dad standing in the doorway. He's wearing his nice clothe roomy green suit and a Stetson hat. Jimmie opes the door. JAMES SR. Why you dressed up like a whiteboy?  81 81. Jimmie looks down at his regular outfit. James Sr. can se caught his son off guard and pivots. JAMES SR. Oh, it’s for your little show, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah. He looks past Jimmie and makes his way inside for the fir time in years. JAMES SR. Man. He peaks in the parlor, nodding to himself as he struts, aided by his cane. Montgomery emerges from the basement with a chair, uphols still ripped from having been tossed on the sidewalk. JAMES SR. You mess up my daddy's chair, Mont- gum-ery?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Oh, no sir. We're, was a... Montgomery looks to Jimmie for help. JAMES SR. You got stage fright huh? James Sr. passes Montgomery, patting his shoulder. JAMES SR. I don't care about the chair, son. He walks down the hall and sits down at the organ. He yan few knobs and begins playing something resembling Bootsy Collins’ “I’d Rather Be With You.” He stops and smiles. JAMES SR. My daddy hated when I played that shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Sr. sits, studying the staircase railing. He runs h cane across the wood.  82. Below, Mont welcomes in Tim Ellory and his wife, holding flier. The couple make their way upstairs, taking a momen drink in the home they've only ever seen from outside. James Sr. JAMES SR. Come on in, don’t be shy. His grandpa built this. Not bad for a black man huh?

dialogues.speaker: TIM ELLORY
dialogues.text: Oh no, very good, very good. chuckles proudly as the couple passes.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I guess you’re not so worried anymore huh? JAMES SR. Na, you still an idiot. But you’re my idiot- James turns to another group admiring the architecture as they pass. James Sr. JAMES SR. Crazy part is we don’t work here, this is ours. But we’re hiring help, applications upstairs, go on ahead. chuckles to his son.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I honestly didn’t think you would come. JAMES SR. Yeah well at my age, a trip like this- (he taps his heart) Figured I should come see how this was all working out though. I know you think I be getting mad just to get mad, but I got my reasons. A moment passes. James Sr.’s eyes float to the front hall below. Jimmie tu to follow his gaze. Wanda stands looking at a framed photo she gave Jimmie. I it, Grandpa Fails theatrically holds a hammer for camera the front step.  83. Wanda looks up. She sees the men and inhales deeply.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Well...the two James'. JAMES SR. (lifting himself) Ahh, Miss Wa-Wa! How you doing little sis? Wanda ascends the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Fine - you look good James. JAMES SR. (laughs) Oh, you know me.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: You too, sweetie. She reaches them and scoops the men into a hug. In his family’s arms, Jimmie melts.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Curtain's up in 10! Nobody moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eclectic audience fills the makeshift theatre. Wanda introduces herself to Andy Roy and Gunna; Tim Ellory pontificates to Bobby who think he's kidding; the hand da teaches Gunna's children air guitar. New faces fill the g between those we've met. The audience falls silent as the lights drop. The curtain creep open to reveal an eerie blue spotlight on Montgomer He stands in profile, dressed exactly like Kofi - oversiz shirt, Jordans and fake ducktails in his hair. Behind him, a diorama of his street in Hunters Point. Sof sounds of the harbor play from a speaker. Montgomery suddenly springs to life.  84.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS KOFI)
dialogues.text: What Imma hit you for, you my folks! Montgomery flips 180 degrees, revealing he's in two-face. second half of his costume is a replica of Nitty.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS NITTY)
dialogues.text: Alright alright, but I cant have soft niggas around me breh. Hit me. Montgomery flips 180 degrees back to "Kofi's" profile.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS KOFI)
dialogues.text: For what bro? For what? Montgomery flips to Nitty.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS NITTY)
dialogues.text: Hit me nigga! Man up! Jimmie enters dressed as Death, a long black robe ends at white skeletal make-up. He slips behind a bush, then a mailbox, ever closer.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS KOFI)
dialogues.text: No bra!

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS NITTY)
dialogues.text: You SOFT breh. They gone call you a bitch at your funeral! Hit me! Kofi erupts, wailing at the air wildly.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS KOFI)
dialogues.text: AhhhhhhHHHHHHHHH!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He cold. He turns to face the crowd in two-face. Lights drop on HP, leaving Kofi alone in the spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS KOFI)
dialogues.text: Alright, yeah nigga! I don't give a fuck! Come see me! Who hiding out there? Man up! Jimmie runs up, raises a finger gun. BANG! - The audience jumps at the sound effect and white strobe flash. BANG! - Another flash. They disappear. DARKNESS .  85. The audience is hushed, all breath taken out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No words. No words...Please send e- hugs. A projection appears, crisp white text against the black: "No words. No words. Please send e-hugs. #KOFIWORLD [world emoji]"

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hazel Greene. 135 likes. The text disappears with a click. Then another: "Just smoked w you the other day. Crazy. [smoking hand emoji]"

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just smoked with you the other day. Crazy. - John Bishop. 206 likes. 10 shares. As another slide appears, we pull wide to see Montgomery now dressed like the street Preacher.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: Are these the people that knew Kofi? The low solemn voices of a black male choir rise.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: Got yelled at by my bitch boss for being late. Sorry theres no timer for grief! Thinking of you always, Koofi - Leah Tanaka. 320 likes. The next text appears.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: (shouting) Man, can't beLIEVE we lost my bra. BUT you wouldn't want me to be sad Ko', so I put my PAIN into my MUSIC!! MAKE sure y'all LIKE the post!! - Rrrrodney Tuck. The curtains widen to reveal that the choir is made up of the street musicians we've met throughout the film.  86.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: (top of his lungs) Mr. Tuck MOVED to FLORIDA 10 years ago. They share ONE mutual friend. His post links to a song called

dialogues.speaker: PEOPLE THAT KNEW KOFI
dialogues.text: More Facebook posts appear on screen, flicking on and off fast to fully read. The choir softens into a funereal hum Montgomery steps forward, slowly making eye contact with person in the room as the house lights fade up on them. In the audience, the Preacher looks touched.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: Kofi had more dimensions than a POST could reflect. Or a PLAY could capture. So I summon YOU. Celebrate the life he lived, not through those who SPEAK loudest, but by the memories he LEFT US ALL- MA‘AM!!! Montgomery points to Loretta. His voice softens.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: - how will you remember Kofi? Loretta hesitates for a moment, unsure of whether or not speak. Montgomery nods encouragingly and Loretta stands.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Kofi was a good kid. He used to walk my niece home when she first moved out here. He kept his hands to himself. He was always a little gentleman. I wish he'd had more time- Loretta's eyes begin to tear as she looks at her sons. Un to continue, she takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: And what about you, sir? Montgomery points to Andy Roy. Andy stands, wipes his fac

dialogues.speaker: ANDY ROY
dialogues.text: Kofi, man? On a board, he was a natural. A lotta people gotta work for it but he had it. He’d like olley the Gonz gap. He’ll be missed.  87. Montgomery nods and turns to Tim Ellory, who blushes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM ELLORY
dialogues.text: Oh I, I never knew him. Montgomery turns to Wanda beside him. She regretfully sha her head as well. Montgomery turns to his Grandpa.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: And you, Grandpa Allen? Bobby nudges Grandpa to alert him. He's already aware.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDPA
dialogues.text: Well, I coached Kofi in Pop Warner. He'd stay behind to help me pack up every day, never made a fuss. Only boy who ever did that.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: And you, my friend? Montgomery points at Jimmie, who has snuck into the middl the audience. Jimmie stands.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: My last memory of Kofi is him talking shit to me. He said some of most fucked up shit anybody ever said to me. But Kofi also got jumped for defending me from older kids at our group home. He didn’t like to fight and he fought for me then. People aren’t one thing.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: THAT. All of it! Montgomery turns to his congregation, smiling proudly.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: What would’ve happened if Kofi had the chance to show himself? All forms of himself? Nobody answers.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: The world had a box for him. And he never pushed beyond it. (scans the walls) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: Perhaps...if Kofi had grown up just a few neighborhoods over - he could've been gentle. And proud to have been that. FRESH starts to tear up.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: But we aren't gathered here solely to mourn. Let us break the boxes. Montgomery bangs his fist against the newly painted wall.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: Let us give each other the courage to SEE and BE SEEN. He points at Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: YOU - Robin Hood of sweets! He points at Wanda's husband, Ricky.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: YOU - once-jailed activist! He whips a finger up at Jimmie.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: And YOU! You, Jimmie, are what is great about this city! You're a fantastic human. A great friend. Jimmie self-consciously shifts as people look at him.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: We're here in this reborn relic because of what this man has done! From Jimmie's expression we can see Montgomery is off-scr

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: Let us see him now. Self-taught historian, carpenter, master decorator, working class hero, lover of lost San Francisco, friend to all friends. YOU. You are seen. Let us really look at Jimmie Fails the Third. The color drains from Jimmie's face as those who haven't already turned to look at him shift in their seats.  89.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: And we don't NEED any of this to see you. This, our little tabernacle, is but a place to congregate today. BUT tomorrow, you, YOU EXIST beyond these walls of your forefathers. He slams his hands against the walls, cracking the wood. whole audience jumps. Jimmie's jaw hardens. Montgomery smiles warmly at Jimmie as he approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: You exist! In every form of yourself! You - you are not this floor! Montgomery lifts the chair Jimmie just fixed and pounds i the floor for effect. Its leg breaks, rattling Montgomery

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Bra, what are you doing? Montgomery freezes, panting.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: You are not this house, Jimmie. And, and, it's time YOU KNOW.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I don’t need to know, let’s stop. James Sr.'’s jaw clenches.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: You extend beyond these wa-

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Alright bra, enough.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, (AS PREACHER)
dialogues.text: Jimmie you don’t need-

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE.
dialogues.text: Silence. Jimmie stares at Montgomery.  83 90.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yes he did. He built this house.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Jim, he didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: He fucking did. How you gone tell me?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I saw the deed. Jimmie looks to everyone, embarrassed. He turns back to M

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You don’t get it...I’m not fucking great. Montgomery studies him, confused.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Get outta here Mont. Montgomery’s confusion turns to shock.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I’m not any of those things! Get out of my house. Jimmie marches out of the room. Chairs squeak as others b to rise slowly. Montgomery stands there, listless. INT./EXT. “THE HOUSE” MASTER BEDROOM - AFTERNOON Jimmie sits in the bay window watching the crowd spill ou onto the street. James Sr. enters and playfully puts his dukes up to Jimmi He softly faux-jabs Jimmie’s chin. Jimmie doesn’t laugh. JAMES SR. What, you in here watching TV? James’ gaze follows Jimmies to the people outside. JAMES SR. Man, they don't deserve to be in here anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Neither do we.  84 91. James Sr. sucks his teeth and starts to roll a cigarette. JAMES SR. You gone really let some ol’ other ass nigga tell you what’s true? C’mon Jayboe, get your spine up, son. Have some pride. James Sr. smiles. Jimmie doesn't. Jimmie finally turns to him. He looks him in the eyes, searching.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I been knowing. (beat) But you say it. Jimmie studies his father. A range of emotions flash over James Sr.'s face. JAMES SR. Say what?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: The truth, I been knowing. This whole time. I’m a liar just like you. Now you say it. James looks at his son, naked. JAMES SR. Fuck outta here, man.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Say it. After a moment, James Sr. lifts himself and passes his so He staggers down the steps, walks towards the front door pulls out the cigarette, his hands trembling. He lights i with the same motion Jimmie does, and opens the door to a strong wind. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Sr. clutches the collar of his coat, bracing for th wind. Jimmie looks on from the window above. The last parcel of life has left the house. Its emptiness heightens its magnificence.  85 86 87 88 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through archways, windows, and door frames - we see Jimmi trapped between the walls that once gave him freedom: Jimmie skates through the deserted house, his face expressionless. Down the hallway, into the kitchen, back the parlor, and round the hallway again. Jimmie stops skating, picks up his board, and sends it crashing into the door frame. THWACK. He screams as he sw it harder. On impact, WE CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie sits, cradling the two splintery halves of his boa Montgomery’s unfinished room stares back at him: tools an rigs sit awkwardly on the ornate shelving. SQUEAK. The gate outside swings shut. Jimmie turns his he

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. "THE HOUSE" MULTIPLE ROOMS
dialogues.text: Jimmie walks down the long hallway, ears piqued - he can footsteps in the brush. He arrives at the back door. Wanda is leaned over something in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: This is the sound of my hands through - well I guess these are asters now? Used to be tulips. Jimmie watches his Aunt take a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Auntie. She turns to see him, bleary-eyed and dejected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanda and Jimmie sit in silence in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: (softly) I been telling people he built it so long I almost forgot it wasn’t true.  93. Jimmie’s barely has any voice left.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: You were telling your truth Jayboe. You were just lying to do it. Wanda flashes a sad smile and looks up at the house. WANDA (CONT’D) This was ours. And then it wasn’t. So you just tell yourself whatever you need to feel like it still is, right? We all did that. But you got a chance to get out from underneath that now.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to. I just want it.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. I seen your daddy build his whole life around that, around some story we got told when we were kids. Shit, I did too. Makes you feel good. Feel special. I don’t think your grandpa even took it that serious to be honest. Folks back then didn’t really care if it was true or not. Just made them happy to have something to aspire to. Wanda looks to Jimmie. WANDA (CONT’D) I’m hella proud of you though - you almost made it real. All this work you did. It’s incredible. But you gotta really ask yourself now if you want that? Spend your life here working on this. Fighting for this. Cause you could make this place yours, I believe you could. But if you leave, it's not your loss, it's San Francisco's. That's how I think about it anyways. Fuck San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: I love you Auntie, I’m sorry.  89 90

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Well I love you and I’m not. You my little, bold, bad-ass, beautiful nephew, man. They hug.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Make all that the opening monologue for your next show.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: Psh more like the pep talk I need to keep me going out there in Antioch. Jimmie hugs her harder. WANDA (CONT’D) You're always welcome out there you know. Jimmie nods, remembering his sobering new reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie sits in a pool of gold light, deep in thought. He’ surrounded by darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie sprawls across a seat, still in a meditative state San Francisco whirs past. Two voices cut through the rattling wheels.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No - it’s 5 dollars for coffee. Not some fancy triple foam ice-cream shit. Coffee. Black.

dialogues.speaker: NINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s absurd. Almost too broken to move, Jimmie turns his head a few degrees to look down the nearly empty car. BECCA and NINA, two thirty-somethings in pencil skirts an blouses, are en route to work. Nina applies foundation, w Becca stares into her coffee, defeated.  91 95.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I need it, to wake up, at 5am, to trek, across town, to temp, with a masters degree. While my mom pretends NOT to freak out.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Ugh, can we go back to New York already?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Seriously fuck this city.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me- The girls turn to Jimmie, caught off guard. He remains slumped.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You don't get to hate San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Er, soooorry, who are you?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks dude, I'll hate what I want.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Do you love it?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: I mean, it's- Yeah, I'm here. Do I have to love it, like...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: You don't get to hate it unless you love it. Jimmie rocks with the train. Nina and Becca turn away.

dialogues.speaker: NINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Classic MUNI shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie walks down the street, holding his broken board li wounded warrior returning from battle. He passes the neighborhood kids playing in a pile of leaves, two women scrubs waiting for a bus, the old man in his fez and kimo  91.1 92 93 96. Jimmie reaches the dock. He looks out over the water. Montgomery sits on his rowboat, watching life on land unf from his usual safe distance. He sees Jimmie. The two hold eye contact. Montgomery collects his fishing gear and begins to paddle HP DOCK - From Montgomery's perspective, we slop towards Jimmie standing on the dock, statuesque. We bump up and d against the chop...less...and less...until we sail smooth to him. Montgomery steps onto the dock and sees his broken board. Jimmie shakes his head, avoiding eye contact. MONTGOMERY (CONT’D) I'm sorry I did that, Jim. It was a stupid play.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: No it wasn’t. I’m sorry I didn’t tell you the truth. I just wanted it to be true, it felt so good, you know.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: That’s okay- Jimmie hugs him tight. Montgomery hugs him back.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Jimmie. You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Starving.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMIE
dialogues.text: Why are you in your tightie whities?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I'm cleaning fish. Jimmie smiles and begins chuckling. It's as if Montgomery quirks were put on earth for him alone to enjoy.

dialogues.text: Jimmie grabs his cot from under the bed and rolls it out. Mont whispers goodnight to a drawing of his mom on the wa Jimmie stares at the ceiling, then at Montgomery. He watc his friend sleep, at peace. Jimmie's eyes float to the painting above Montgomery's head: A boat struggles against the chop of the San Francisco Ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montgomery wakes, one side of his hair flattened from the pillow. He sits up to find Jimmie's cot rolled up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montgomery walks into the living room. Grandpa lies aslee the recliner under a blanket. Montgomery shuts off the TV He enters the kitchen and finds a flier folded in half. Below the play’s header, “THE LAST BLACK MAN IN SAN FRANCISCO,” is "MONTGOMERY" in beautiful handwriting. Montgomery takes a seat and opens the flyer. It reads:

dialogues.speaker: BEING MY BEST FRIEND."
dialogues.text: Montgomery stares down at the card and then out the windo With the twinkling harp-plucks of Sam Cooke's “DEEP RIVER we push towards the window. The song rises as we see that Mont's red rowboat is gone. Montgomery looks out at the B  98 98.1 98.2 98.3 98.4 98.5 98.6 99 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. BUS STOP - Montgomery sits at a bus stop, mumbling t himself as he waits patiently. INT. GROCERY STORE - Montgomery, the last black man in Sa Francisco, stands behind the fish counter. He stares, eye slightly out of focus, at the rows of dead fish on ice. INT. BUS - Montgomery sits on the bus, staring out. EXT. THE BAY - We glide over deep water and slowly tilt u find Jimmie, rowing against the chop like Montgomery's painting. Freedom, fear, and determination fill his face. EXT. "THE HOUSE" - Montgomery stares up at the now lifele house from across the street. Stripped of its molding and intricate detail, the renovated facade now boasts a two c garage beneath it. INT. "THE HOUSE" PARLOR & FRONT HALLWAY - Young couples p between rooms, whispering in hushed tones. Montgomery flo past them like a ghost. The house is staged for purchase: Ikea couch, reclaimed wood table, cardboard books and wax Montgomery picks up a fake fruit and stares at it in his hand. He glances into the library with a purposeful look. INT. "THE HOUSE" LIBRARY - A couple inspects the built-in bookcases, failing to notice one of the shelves behind th slowly creak open and reveal a shadowy cavity. From the darkness, out leaps a dust-covered Montgomery, fingers gnarled like a vengeful ghost! Just before they c scream—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montgomery dangles his feet over the edge of the dock. Th faint sounds of sirens blare somewhere far away. Behind him, a candlelit vigil makes its way past his hous with signs reading RIP KOFI. They cast flickering gold sh onto Montgomery's reflection in the water. He stares out the Bay as the incoming mist begins to fog his view. END.
